ldl.description: LDL (Low-Density Lipoprotein) is often referred to as 'bad cholesterol'. These lipoprotein particles are the primary transporters of cholesterol in the bloodstream, delivering it from the liver to cells throughout the body. When LDL levels are elevated, excess cholesterol can accumulate in the inner walls of arteries, initiating a process called atherosclerosis. This buildup of plaque, composed of fats, cholesterol, calcium, and other substances, narrows the arteries, making them stiff and less flexible. This can impede blood flow to vital organs, increasing the risk of serious cardiovascular events such as coronary artery disease, angina (chest pain), heart attack (myocardial infarction), stroke (cerebrovascular accident), and peripheral artery disease. Factors significantly influencing LDL levels include dietary intake of saturated and trans fats, physical inactivity, obesity, genetic predisposition (familial hypercholesterolemia), and certain underlying medical conditions like diabetes and hypothyroidism.

hdl.description: HDL (High-Density Lipoprotein) is known as 'good cholesterol' due to its role in reverse cholesterol transport. HDL particles circulate in the bloodstream and actively scavenge excess cholesterol from peripheral tissues, including the walls of arteries. They then transport this cholesterol back to the liver for processing and eventual excretion from the body. This process helps to prevent or slow down the formation of atherosclerotic plaques. Higher levels of HDL are associated with a reduced risk of cardiovascular disease, as they promote the removal of cholesterol from arteries and possess anti-inflammatory and antioxidant properties that protect the endothelium (the inner lining of blood vessels). Factors that can positively influence HDL levels include regular aerobic exercise, maintaining a healthy weight, avoiding smoking, and moderate alcohol consumption in some individuals. Genetic factors also play a role in determining HDL levels.
